section.p: Are roadmap and goals are always subject to discussion on the developer's list. As new people join with new focus and interests, the things we do as a project adapt.
If you have an idea, come join the community and talk about it. Note that you will need to subscribe to the mail list

section.name: High-Level Roadmap
section.p: Our project goal is an open source, compatible implementation of Java SE 5. It's a major task being done by a community of volunteers. Thus, the following is an approximate roadmap for what the project hopes to achieve in the next year.

li.strike: Aug 2006: 85% of Java SE 5 class library coverage
Aug 2006: regular distributions of pre-completion Harmony JDK and HDK suitable for development and testing
Sept 2006: 90% of \Java SE 5 class library coverage

ul.li: Q4 2006: ASF completes process of securing Java SE TCK license

li.strike: Oct 2006: 92% of Java SE 5 class library coverage
Nov 2006: 95% of Java SE 5 class library coverage

ul.li: Dec 2006: 97% of Java SE 5 class library coverage
Q1 2007: 100% Java SE 5 class library coverage
Q1 2007: DRLVM is stable with reasonable performance
Q1 2007: begin testing with TCK
Q1 2007: work begins on Java SE 6 features
Feb 2007: Jave SE 5 JDK toolset complete
Q2 2007: TCK certification of Harmony completed
Q2 2007: Apache Harmony SE 5 JDK and JRE released
Q4 2007: Apache Harmony SE 6 JDK and JRE released

Q? 2008: Apache Harmony SE 7 JDK and JRE released. Note: The Java SE 7 JSR has not yet been proposed by Sun. We assume 18 months from start of JSR to completion. We hope to deliver Harmony's implementation of Java SE 7 at the same time Sun does.

section.name: TODO List
section.p: The following is a collection of things that the project community has listed as needing to be done. This list is not exhaustive. If you wish to add an item to this list, or discuss or even volunteer to work on an item, please join us on the Harmony mail list.
The following sections describe the high-level areas of effort, and tasks that have been identified for those areas.

subsection.name: General
subsection.p: As part of the JDK that Harmony will distribute, we'll include the full set of tools that Java programmers expect to find in any JDK. For maximum portablility, we plan to write all of the tools in Java, using the Harmony launcher as the portable native code that starts the VM and invokes the tool. Currently, we have javac completed via the Eclipse compiler, but we need the following:

ul.li: javac (Done), javadoc, apt, appletviewer, jar, jdb, javah, javap, extcheck
keytool, jarsigner, policytool, kinit, klist, ktab
native2ascii,rmic, rmiregistry, rmid, serialver
tnameserv, idlj, orbd, servertool
pack200, unpack200
htmlconverter, javaws

subsection.p: Again, we have the portable launcher framework - we just need volunteers.

From the beginning of our project, we've had a strong interest and focus on modularity This dedication has paid off in our class library development, as we've been able to evaluate competing implementations of RMI and math, as well as allow developers to isolate development on one module.

The modularity story for the class library is reasonable complete at this point, as we have completed the modularization of the native code as well. However, there is plenty of work to be done with our virtual machines - the goal being able to define a set of standard interfaces to which modular VM components can be written.

subsection.name: Build Engineering
subsection.p: Build engineering in Harmony is a complicated subject, as we are building on multiple platforms in multiple languages. So far, we have support for our Windows and Linux ports, but our porting plans indiciate that we'll need to revisit given the differnet toolchains. There are many things to do in this area, many not listed.
Currently, the project has been releasing snapshots of our class library, but now that we have the DRLVM virtual machine, we can start doing complete snapshot builds of a JRE, as well as the HDK

ul.li: Switch to use system libraries, dynamically where appropriate - libz, libpng, libjpeg, liblcms, libicu*, etc.

Create regular schedule for snapshots and automate. Maybe every two weeks for now?
HDK - libraries, jars, headers
JDK - tools + JRE
JRE = classlib + DRLVM
Federated build - abliity to builds a complete JDK from top level using choice of project VM
Agreement between project parts (DRLVM, classlib) on things like debug/release flag, structure of artifacts (model after classlib for now)
Common dependency pool for all projet parts to share
Switch DRLVM build to a class library-like ant + make configuration
Remove assumption in class library build system that all that uses make is linux.

subsection.name: Build-Test Framework
subsection.p: The goal of this part of the Harmony project, the build-test framework, is make it easy for anyone to setup the CI infrastructure for the project and submit automated reports on building and testing of the project codebase on that platform.

There is an
initial implementation in place in SVN, but much more work is needed. Ideas include:

ul.li: Send mail to project on success/fail transition
Create live "status dashboard" with a summary of results from all tested platforms, as wella s history for each tested platform.
Integrate with JAPI
Integrate with Mauve for further class library testing
Integrate with test-coverage tool (ex emma for auto-generated reports.
Externalize local properties into a 'test.properties' file for easy of localization.

subsection.name: Performance, Stability and Reliability
subsection.p: Our goal is a high-performance, stable and compatible implementation of Java SE 5. While passing the TCK is a measure of compatibility with the standard, performance and stability is something that must be achieved independently. We are looking to:

ol.li: Define a set of stress, stability and performance tests that are freely available and easy to automate in our build-test framework.
Measure and monitor baseline peformance using these tests with our standard builds across our supported platform matrix.
Identify and fix stability and performance problems.

subsection.name: Class Library
subsection.p: The class library is an important (and large!) part of the Java SE platform. While we have made significant progress so far (~80% at last check), there are many, many interesting things remaining to be done

ul.li: java.util.concurrency: integration of Doug Lea's RI package. Goal is to use unmodified code from the 166 expert group and implent whatever support is needed by the VM and rest of class library. (in progress)
CORBA: re-use the Apache Yoko project (currently in incubator) as the required implementation of CORBA nad related support classes (in progress)
JMX: currently we have the standard MX4J jars integrated, but looking to see what kind of collaboration or unification we can achieve with the MX4J project. (in progress)
Test coverage - we need to greatly increase our unit tests (functionaly, spec, implementation)

subsection.name: DRLVM
subsection.p: VM is a critical part of the Java SE platform. As usual, there are many, many interesting things remaining to be done

ul.li: Known non bug issues and limitations This is a list of problems known to exist in drlvm which may or may not manifest themself in tests.

Improve kernel classes/natives code sharing This is a list of isolated development tasks which do not require advanced knowledge of VM and could be a nice start for newbies to get acquainted with the code.

subsection.name: Porting Matrix
subsection.p: Another motivation of the Harmony project is to provide a portable implementation that is available on many platforms and operating systems. Currently, our interests are:

tr.th:
Linux
RHEL, SLES, Debian, Gentoo, Ubuntu, Fedora

subsection.name: Application-Driven Project Advancement
subsection.p: As we now have a fairly usable class library and virtual machine, we wish to make it easy for the broad Java user community to help us ensure that the Harmony class library supports the classes necessary for the most popular and used applications out there. While we will complete the class library, tools like this will help us do it in a way that prioritizes the most useful first, enabling even more users to test our software and participate in the project. So far, there have been a few tools donated, but no concerted effort to package for ease of use.

ul.li: Harmony-165 - tool to compare an applications required classes with what is available in Harmony
Harmony-565 - another tool for reporting class coverage for applications
